commits.subject: feat: implement Negotiation Mode UI changes
commits.body:
Based on Discovery Framework findings, implement "Simplified by Default" approach
for client-facing negotiation sessions.

Input Field Enhancements:
- Add benchmark property for industry standard badges (e.g., "Industry: 5-15%")
- Add essential property to control field grouping
- InputField displays benchmark badges next to labels

Calculator Page Refactor:
- Progressive disclosure: Essential inputs visible, Advanced collapsed
- Sensitivity/Projections moved to collapsible "Advanced Analysis" section
- Transfer Pricing collapsed by default (shows risk badge)
- One-click save with auto-generated names
- Saved options count shown in action bar

This aligns with the 5 design principles from discovery:
1. Client in the room - cleaner, less overwhelming UI
2. Neutral ground first - industry benchmarks prominently displayed
3. Show both sides - Developer/Buyer results always visible
4. Progressive complexity - advanced features tucked away
5. Compare to decide - prominent save, easy comparison flow
commits.title: implement Negotiation Mode UI changes

commits.subject: docs: add Negotiation Mode design and UI audit
commits.body:
Created NEGOTIATION_MODE.md with:
- 5-minute client walkthrough script
- Screen-by-screen requirements for negotiation use case
- Feature visibility matrix (show/hide by mode)
- Implementation recommendation: "Simplified by Default"

Completed UI audit against 5 design principles:
- Client in the room: Partial - tabs may confuse
- Neutral ground first: Fix needed - no benchmark badges
- Show both sides: Good - Developer/Buyer panels work
- Progressive complexity: Fix needed - all inputs visible
- Compare to decide: Partial - save requires modal

Created prioritised fix list:
- Priority 1: Industry badges, collapse advanced features, one-click save
- Priority 2: Group inputs into Essential/Advanced
- Priority 3: Comparison view enhancements
commits.title: add Negotiation Mode design and UI audit

commits.subject: feat: architecture redesign - Phase 1 foundation
commits.body:
Migrate from vanilla JS to TypeScript + SvelteKit monorepo architecture
for improved maintainability, type safety, and testability.

Changes:
- Add monorepo structure with pnpm workspaces
- Create @model-pear/calculator package with TypeScript
  - Extract Model 1 (Cost-Plus) with full type definitions
  - Add comprehensive test suite (44 tests)
  - Define types for entities, results, and calculations
- Create @model-pear/web SvelteKit app shell
  - Set up Tailwind CSS configuration
  - Add landing page with mode selector
  - Add proof-of-concept UI for Model 1
  - Configure static adapter for GitHub Pages
- Move existing vanilla JS code to legacy/ folder
- Add ARCHITECTURE.md documenting the redesign

Build commands:
- pnpm install: Install dependencies
- pnpm test: Run calculator tests
- pnpm build: Build all packages

This is Phase 1 of 4 in the migration plan.

commits.subject: Refactor testing to workflow-based logical assertions
commits.body:
Replace numerical math tests with readable workflow-based tests that verify
displayed values are logically correct based on user actions and inputs.

Changes:
- Create ASSERTIONS library with reusable logical checks
- Each assertion has: field name, readable logic formula, description
- Define WORKFLOW_SCENARIOS that read like user stories
- Tests now verify "Developer Revenue = Cost × (1 + Markup)" logic
- Not testing math (1000 × 1.1 = 1100), testing business logic
- Update UI to display stories, workflow badges, and assertion formulas

commits.subject: Improve test documentation with business rules and formulas
commits.body:
Each test case now includes:
- businessRule: Explains WHY the test exists (accounting/tax logic)
- formula: Step-by-step calculation showing HOW expected values derive
- source: Reference to documentation (CALCULATIONS.md, IAS 38, OECD, etc.)

The expanded test view in the UI now displays these fields with
appropriate formatting:
- Business Rule: Blue-tinted box explaining the accounting principle
- Formula: Monospace green text showing the calculation steps
- Source: Reference badge linking to standards/documentation

commits.subject: Add testing lab tab for validating calculation correctness
commits.body:
New feature that allows testing pre-populated input combinations against
expected outcomes to verify calculations are working correctly.

Features:
- Testing tab with "Run Tests" button to execute all tests at once
- Individual test execution with detailed pass/fail results
- Pre-defined test cases for Model 1 (all variants), Model 2, Model 3
- Edge case tests (zero cost, high margin, custom tax rates)
- Filter tests by model for focused testing
- Expandable test details showing inputs and expected vs actual values
- Summary panel with pass rate, duration, and error counts
- Custom test capture from current calculator state

commits.body: Refactor monolithic app.js into modular architecture

commits.subject: Refactor monolithic app.js into modular architecture
commits.body:
Major refactoring to improve maintainability, testability, and developer experience.

## Changes

### Architecture
- Extracted 6,377-line monolithic app.js into 12 specialized modules
- Organized code into 7 directories with clear separation of concerns
- Implemented ES6 module system with proper imports/exports
- Created main app.js orchestrator (now ~500 lines)

### New Directory Structure
- config/ - Global configuration and application state (1 file)
- framework/ - Three-layer framework implementation (4 files)
  - model-families.js - Model family groupings
  - categories.js - Layer 1: Core function categories
  - delivery.js - Layer 2: Delivery mechanisms
  - services.js - Layer 3: Service models
- models/ - All 20 revenue model definitions (1 file, ~1,250 lines)
- utils/ - Utility functions for formatting, validation, calculations (1 file, ~810 lines)
- charts/ - Chart rendering with ApexCharts (1 file, ~730 lines)
- calculators/ - Calculation engines (2 files, ~1,300 lines)
  - engine.js - Core calculation engine
  - client-budget.js - Client budget calculator
- ui/ - User interface logic (5 files, ~1,600 lines)
  - forms.js - Dynamic form generation
  - events.js - Event handlers
  - initialization.js - App initialization logic
  - admin.js - Admin panel functionality
  - modals.js - Tooltip and modal functions

### Technical Improvements
- Resolved circular dependencies using dependency injection pattern
- Each module has clear, single responsibility
- Proper encapsulation with explicit exports
- Maintained backward compatibility with existing HTML
- All JavaScript files pass syntax validation

### Documentation Updates
- Updated README.md with new project structure and module descriptions
- Added modular architecture benefits section
- Updated QUICK_START_ALIGNMENT.md with modular structure examples
- Added notes to IMPLEMENTATION_PROGRESS.md and FRAMEWORK_ALIGNMENT_PLAN.md
- Added comprehensive changelog entry for refactoring

### Benefits
- 92% reduction in main file size (6,377 lines → ~500 lines)
- Better maintainability and code navigation
- Individual modules can be unit tested independently
- Reduced cognitive load for developers
- Easier to add new revenue models or features
- Improved scalability for future development

### Testing
- All JavaScript files validated for syntax errors
- Module structure verified
- Import/export dependencies confirmed
- No breaking changes to existing functionality

commits.subject: Merge pull request #19 from devmade-ai/claude/refactor-budget-client-costs-YQMIH
commits.body: Add Client Budget Calculator mode - client/cost perspective

commits.subject: Add Client Budget Calculator mode - client/cost perspective
commits.body:
This commit introduces a new Client Budget Calculator mode that complements
the existing Vendor (forward) and Growth (reverse) modes. The new mode allows
clients/buyers to input their budget and find optimal pricing options.

Key Changes:
- UI: Added third calculator mode button "Client" (Budget Options)
- HTML: New client budget input section with budget, flexibility, and priority options
- JS: Implemented client budget calculation logic with 3 optimization strategies:
  * Maximum Capacity: Get the most users/seats within budget
  * Best Value: Optimize for lowest cost per unit
  * Budget Conscious: Leave 20% buffer
- Budget flexibility options: Strict, Moderate (±10%), Flexible (±20%)
- Results display: Shows 3-6 pricing options with cost, capacity, and value metrics
- Color-coded badges: Green (within budget), Yellow (within flex), Red (over)
- Docs: Updated README.md and claude.md with client mode documentation

The three modes now serve different perspectives:
1. Vendor Mode: Business calculating revenue from pricing parameters
2. Growth Mode: Business with revenue target finding required inputs
3. Client Mode: Buyer with budget finding best pricing options

All 20 revenue models now support the client budget calculator.

Features:
- View toggle buttons to switch between Form and Table views
- Single model table: displays all parameters in a structured table with Parameter/Value/Unit/Description columns
- Multi-model comparison table: side-by-side parameter comparison across selected models
- Real-time synchronization between form and table inputs
- Table view automatically updates when models are selected/deselected
- View toggle only shown in forward calculator mode with selected models

Benefits:
- Power users can quickly edit parameters in spreadsheet-style interface

commits.subject: Fix empty sections appearing between metrics and cumulative chart
commits.body:
The issue was caused by a grid container wrapping the secondary charts
that was never hidden, even when its children were hidden. This resulted
in empty space appearing in the comparison view.

Changes:
- Added 'secondaryChartsGrid' ID to the parent grid container (index.html:181)
- Made parent grid hidden by default instead of individual containers
- Updated all JavaScript to show/hide the parent grid instead of individual containers
- Removed redundant visibility management of child containers

This ensures the grid and its gap spacing only appear when charts are
actually being displayed, eliminating the empty section between metrics
and the cumulative revenue chart.

commits.subject: Adapt currency and default values for South African market
commits.body:
- Changed currency formatter from USD to ZAR (South African Rand)
- Updated all currency labels from ($) to (R) throughout the app
- Converted all model default values to appropriate South African Rand amounts
  - One-time license: R15,000 (was $499)
  - Subscription: R1,800/month (was $99)
  - Per-seat: R450/seat (was $25)
  - Usage-based: R0.90/unit (was $0.05)
  - Tiered pricing: R520/R1,800/R5,400 (was $29/$99/$299)
  - Retainer: R90,000/month (was $5,000)
  - Managed services: R180,000/month (was $10,000)
  - Enterprise models: R9M+ annual contracts (was $500k)
  - All other models scaled proportionally using ~18:1 exchange rate

This aligns the calculator with South African market pricing context
that was already present in the LAYER_1_CATEGORIES configuration.

commits.subject: Implement Layer 2/3 framework modifiers across all pricing models
commits.body:
This commit completes the calculation engine integration for the framework alignment:

✅ Added central applyFrameworkModifiers() helper function
- Consistently applies Layer 2 (Delivery) and Layer 3 (Service) modifiers
- Handles self-hosted one-time conversions
- Adds managed services base fees
- Adjusts pricing, churn rates, and CAC

✅ Updated generateAllForms() to use category-specific defaults
- Applies pricing defaults from LAYER_1_CATEGORIES
- Shows category-specific hint text for ranges and benchmarks
- Maps common inputs (price, churnRate, conversionRate) to context data

✅ Updated all 20 pricing model calculate() functions:
Core models:
- per-seat: Applies modifiers to seat pricing and churn
- usage-based: Applies modifiers to per-unit pricing
- tiered: Applies modifiers to all three tier prices
- freemium: Applies modifiers to paid tier pricing and churn
- subscription: Applies modifiers to monthly price and churn

Additional models (15 total):
- one-time, retainer, managed-services, pay-per-transaction
- credits-token, time-materials, fixed-price, outcome-based
- open-core, marketplace, revenue-share, advertising
- ela, data-licensing, white-label

Each model now:
1. Calls applyFrameworkModifiers() at start of calculate()
2. Uses modifiers.price instead of raw input price
3. Uses modifiers.churn instead of raw churn rate
4. Adds managed services revenue when applicable
5. Includes debug info (appliedPrice, appliedChurnRate)

This enables the full framework flow:
Category → Models → Delivery → Service → Calculate

Next steps: Testing and industry benchmarks display
